head.title: Yogurt Can Lower Heat in Red Pepper, Curry Powder or Cumin

hedline.hl1: Yogurt Can Lower Heat in Red Pepper, Curry Powder or Cumin

abstract.p: Florence Fabricant Food column on some seafood recipes that benefit from spice, as well as another ingredient like yogurt or cream to temper the heat; drawings (M)

block.p: SPICES can blast with both barrels or they can subtly lift a dish to a higher level of flavorful complexity. It is just a matter of how they are used.
Hot red peppers, curry powder and cumin are often among the ingredients in recipes these days. Ideally, they make the mouth glow with delight but do not terrify the palate with some macho assault.
SPICES can blast with both barrels or they can subtly lift a dish to a higher level of flavorful complexity. It is just a matter of how they are used.
Hot red peppers, curry powder and cumin are often among the ingredients in recipes these days. Ideally, they make the mouth glow with delight but do not terrify the palate with some macho assault.

Here are three seafood recipes that benefit from spice. In each instance, there is another ingredient, like cream, yogurt or oil, to temper the potential blowtorch. Feel free to adjust the degree of spice, if you wish, but remember to do so in small increments so the dish does not go over the line.
The result should be a richness that would be impossible without the spice.
Creamy Spiced Mussels Total time: 45 minutes
1/2teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes, or to taste
1. Heat the oil in a heavy three-quart saucepan. Add the shallots and saute until they start to brown. Stir in the tomatoes and continue cooking until they soften. Stir in the wine.
2. Add the mussels, cover and cook until they open, about eight minutes.

3. Using a slotted spoon, transfer the mussels to each of four warm soup plates. Add the pepper flakes and cream to the cooking liquid in the pan and bring to a boil. Season to taste with salt. Pour over each portion of mussels and serve.
Spiced Lobster Salad Total time: 30 minutes
1. Dice the lobster, put it in a bowl and fold in the onion and minced mint and cilantro. Cover and refrigerate.
2. Peel and dice half the cucumber, put it in a bowl and add the yogurt, cumin, lemon juice and lemon zest. Combine the lobster mixture with the yogurt dressing. Season with a pinch or two of salt.

4. Peel the remaining cucumber and slice it into thin rounds. Arrange the rounds in a circle on each of four salad plates. Spoon a mound of the lobster salad in the center of each, garnish with mint and serve.
Flounder In Curried Escabeche Total time: 1 hour
1small red bell pepper, cored and sliced thin
Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste
1. Combine the flour and a teaspoon and a half of curry powder on a dinner plate. Dip the flounder in this mixture to coat each side.

2. Heat three tablespoons of the oil in a large skillet, preferably nonstick. Saute the flounder a few minutes on each side, until lightly browned and cooked through. Transfer the flounder to a serving platter.

3. Lower the heat under the skillet and add the onion, pepper, fennel and garlic. Saute slowly until the vegetables are tender and lightly browned. Stir in the remaining curry powder, adjusting the amount to taste, and deglaze with the fish stock and lemon juice.

4. Remove from heat and add the remaining olive oil. Season with salt and pepper. Spoon the mixture over the fish and garnish with cilantro. This dish can be served immediately or can be set aside at room temperature about an hour before serving.
